p: Four biological control agents have been released in Australia: Algarobius bottimeri and A. prosopis (seed-feeding bruchids), Evippe species (a leaf-tying moth) and Prosopidopsylla flava (a sap sucker) ( van Klinken et al. 2003 ; van Klinken 2012). Two have established widely ( A. prosopis, Evippe species), and the latter has had noticeable impacts on Prosopis populations through reducing long-term growth rates ( van Klinken 2012). Biological control in Australia has been more successful than in other places like South Africa and the benefit-to-cost ratios are positive (0.5), with expectations to increase in the future ( Page and Lacey 2006). The release of more agents is recommended to further improve control ( van Klinken et al. 2003 ; van Klinken 2012).
